And the eorlus owne eyer,
I wolde nothing off their,
Broche ne bye.
I wolde aske tham na mare
But hyr body all bare,
And we frendes for evermare,
What doel that I drye!"

LG.HEAD: XXXVI.
LG.L: That sqwyer seyde hys avyse,
"Think that ȝe ere enemys;
Lat some wye that ys wys
Walk one thus nede,
ffor I dare saffly swere,
Gyff he take the in werre,
Alle Englond here
Wold spek of thi dede,
And say hyt ys a ffolly,
ffor to love thin enemy,
Gyf thou gett a vylony,
But maugré to mede;
Other ladyes wolde say,
Myȝthe no womman the apay
Bete maiede Mylder the may,
Vlonkest on wede?"

LG.HEAD: XXXVII.
LG.L: Then saide syr Degrivaunt,
"Thou shal not mak thin avaunt
That I shall be recreaunt,
ffor frende ne for foo!
Thou woldest halde me ful made,
ffor the erle ful rade;
Troust I be so made
To leve my love so?
At even arme the well
Bothe in yren and in stel,
And we shullen to the castel
Bytwyx us owne two;
Sertenly this ylke nyȝth,
I wylle see hyr with syȝth,
And spek with that byrde bryȝth,
ffor wel or for wo!"

LG.HEAD: XXXVIII.
LG.L: Tow ryche cou[r]sers thei hente,
And forthe here weys thei wente;
Undir a lynd or thei lente,
By a launde syde.
Whyle hyt dawed lyȝth day,
The eorle buskede on hys way,
Out at a posterne to play
With knyȝth of pryde.
Sir Degrivaunt helde hym styll,
Whyle the eorle passyde the hyll,
And seid hys squier hym tyll
Pryvaly that tyde,
"I rede we hye us ful ȝerne
In at the ȝond posterne,
And let us halde us in derne
The burde tyll abyde."

LG.HEAD: XXXIX.
LG.L: Syr Degrivaunt tok non hede;
In at the posterne he ȝede.
The porter hade ben in drede,
Hadd he ben thare.
He that the ȝatt schulde kepe,
He was go for to slepe;
In at an orcherd thei lepe,
Y-armede as thei ware.
The knyȝt and the squiere
Resten in a rosere,
Tylle the day wex clere,
Undurne and mare;
Whyle that hurde thei a bell
Ryng in a chapell;
To chyrche the gay dammisel
Buskede hyr ȝare.

LG.HEAD: XL.
LG.L: Sche come in a vyolet,
With whyȝthe perl overfret,
And saphyrus therinne i-sett
On everyche a syde;
All of pall work fyn,
With miche and nevyn,
Anerlud with ermyn,
And overt for pryde.
To tell hure botenus was toore,
Anamelede with azoure;
With topyes and trechoure
Overtrasyd that tyde,
Sche was recevyd a spanne
Of any lyvand manne;
Off rede golde the rybanne
Glemyd hure syde.

LG.HEAD: XLI.
LG.L: Hyr here was hyȝthtyd on hold
With a coronal of golde;
Was never made upon mold
A worthelyche wyȝth.
Sche was frely and fair,
And well hyr semed hyr geyr,
With ryche boses a payr,
That derely were by-dyȝth
With a front endent,
With peyrl of orient,
Out of Syprus was sent
To that burd bryȝth;
Hur kerchevus was curyus,
Hyr vyssag ful gracious.
Sir Degrivaunt that amerus
Had joye of that syȝth.

LG.HEAD: XLII.
LG.L: By that the masse was i-seid,
The halle was ryaly areyd;
The eorlle hadd i-revayd,
And in hys ȝerd lyȝthus:
Trompers tromped to the mete,
They weshen and went to sette,
So duden all the grete,
Ladyes and knyȝttus.
When the lordys were drawin,
Ladyes rysen, was not to leyn,
And wentten to chaumbur aȝeyne,
Anon thei hom dyȝthus;
Dame Mildore and hyr may
Went to the orcherd to play,
Ther syr Degrivaunt lay
Thei com anon-ryȝthus.

LG.HEAD: XLIII.
LG.L: Syr Degrivaunt withouten lett
In an aley he hyr mete,
And godlyche he hyr gret,
That worthelyche wyȝth,
And seyd, "Certys, lady and fre,
Jhesu save the and see,
Thi servaunt wold I be,
My trouȝth I the plyȝth!
I wold spek, hadd I space,
Privély in a place;
My lyff ys loken in thi grace,
Thou worthilyche wyȝth!"
The byrd was gretely affraid,
But natheles hoo was wel paid,
He was so ryally arayd,
That commolyche knyȝth.

LG.HEAD: XLIV.
LG.L: The byrd answerus on hyȝth,
"Whethur thou be squier or knyȝth,
Me thenkus thou not dost ryȝth,
Sothely to say;
That thou commyst armid on werre,
To maydenus to afferre,
That walkes in here erbere
Privély to play.
By God and by Sent Jame,
Y know not thi name,
Thou erte gretely to blame,
I tell the in fay!"
The knyȝt kneled hyr tyll,
"Medame, yf hit be ȝoure wyll,
I graunt I have done yll,
I may not ageyn-say.

LG.HEAD: XLV.
LG.L: "As God save me of synne,
I myȝth with non other gynne
Tyl ȝour spech for to wynne,
By day ne be nyȝthe;
ffro I telle the my name,
I am not for to blame,
And yf hit turne me to grame,
I shal anon-ryȝth:
Hyt ys I, syre Degryvaunt!
And hit were ȝoure avenaunt,
I wold be ȝoure servaunt,
As y am trew knyȝth!"
Sho seyd, "Tratur, lat be the,
Be Hym that dyed on tre,
My lord hymself shal the see
Hanged on hyȝth!"

LG.HEAD: XLVI.
LG.L: Than syr Degrivaunt louȝh,
As he stod under the bow,
"Madame, ȝe wyteth me with wouȝh,
Gyf hyt be ȝoure wyll!
I had never no gylt,
Of al that blod that was spylt,
That wyll I prove, as thou wylt,
Above the ȝondur hyll:
Corteys lady and wyse,
As thou arte pervenke of pryse,
I do me on thi gentryse,
Why wolt thou me spyll?
And I be slayn in this stede,
Thou shalt be cause of my dede;
ȝet wolt thou rew that rede,
And lyke hyt ful yll!"

LG.HEAD: XLVII.
LG.L: Sche said, "Tratur, thou shalt bye!
Why were thou so hardye
To do me this vylanye,
By day ar by nyȝth?
For oure folk that thou hast slayn,
Thou shalt be honged and drawyn,
Therof my fadyr wol be fayn
To see that with syȝth!"
The knyȝt spak to this fre,
"Seththe hyt may no bettur be,
Go feche all hys many
With me for to fyȝth;
And here my trouȝth er I leton,
The geyest of hem shal gron,
Gyf ther come fourty for on,
My trouȝth I the plyȝth!

LG.HEAD: XLVIII.
LG.L: "And her my trouȝth I the plyȝthe,
Tho that lepeth now ful lyȝth
Shal be ffay, and we ffyȝth,
ffor all here michel pryde!"
The stout man was astered,
Hys squiere rauȝth hym hys swerd;
Thanne the borlych berde
No lenger durst byde.
Tyl hyr chaumbur sche went,
And swore the knyȝth shulde be schent.
The mayde hur hood of hoe hent,
And knelyd that tyde;
"Meydame, oppon ȝowlus nyȝthe
My waryson ȝe me hyȝth;
Y ne axe the bote ȝonde knyȝth
To slep by my syde!"

LG.HEAD: XLIX.
LG.L: Blyve the burde gat a blame,
But sche ne let for no schame,
That sche ne asked the same,
Sothly to say.
"Damesel, go do thi best,
I pray the let me have my rest;
Go and glad thi gest,
In all the devyl way!
ffor as ever Gode me save,
Haddest thou asked a knave,
The symplust that I have,
Hadd be more to my pay:
I swere the by Goddus grace,
Come he never in this place,
He passed never syche a pace,
By nyȝthe ne by day!"

LG.HEAD: L.
LG.L: "Maydame," sche seid, "gramercy
Of thi gret cortesy."
Blyve a chaumbur ther-by
Busked was ȝare,
And in sche feches the knyȝth,
Prevaly withouten syȝthe,
As wymmen conn mychel slyȝthe,
And ther wylles ware.
Sche dyȝt to hys sopere
The foules of the ryvere,
Ther was no deyntethus to dere,
Ne spyces to spare.
The knyȝt sat at hys avenaunt,
In a gentyl jesseraunt;
The mayd mad hym semblaunt,
And hys met schare.

LG.HEAD: LI.
LG.L: Of all the met that she schare,
The knyȝt ete never the mare;
Whan he syȝthe ful sare,
The mayden gan smyle.
Sone aftyr he seys,
"What useth the eorl a-dayes?
Hontes he ar revayes?
What does he this whyle?"
The burd answerus agayn,
"Seththe hys chyvalry was slayn,
He passed never out on the playn
Halvendel a myle;
Hys hurtus has hym so y-deryd,
He has byn gretely afferyd:
The ȝatus has byn ay y-speryd
ffor dred of thi gyle!"

LG.HEAD: LII.
LG.L: "Or hys ȝatis be y-speryd,
I shal mak hym afferyd,
I shal schak hym by the berd
The nexte tyme we mete!
But I let for hur sake,
That I have chosen to my mak,
Sche doys me unwynly to wak,
With wongus ful wete!
I had levere sche were sauȝthe,
Then all the golde in hys auȝthe,
And I in armus hade y-lauȝthe
That commely and swete.
Thane durste I saffly syng,
Was never emporoure ne kyng
More at hys lykyng,
And honde I the hete."

LG.HEAD: LIII.
LG.L: The mayd answerus aȝeyn,
"Me think thou travelus in vayn,
Thou hast oure kunred y-slayn,
How myȝt hit so be?
I swere the by Godus myȝthe,
Com thou ever in hur syȝth,
Thou bes honged on hyȝthe
Hyie one a tre!
Hyr preferrys par-amoure
Both dukes and emperoure;
Hyt were hyr disonowre
For to taken the:
The duke of Gerle for hir has sent,
That he wol have a tornament,
Hyt ys my lordys assent,
Withynne for to be.

LG.HEAD: LIV.
LG.L: "Tho duke comes of so gret arey
To juste and to tornay;
Thou comes nat at that play
By counsayl of me.
Hyt is my lordys ensent,
Come thou to that torniment,
Sertaynly thou be schent
And all thi meynye!"
"Damesele, withouten drede,
Thou hast warnyd me of this dede;
Of this gret gentyl rede
God for-ȝelde the!
And y swere be Sent Luke,
I shal juste with that duke,
Or I gete a rebuke,
How ever that hyt be!

LG.HEAD: LV.
LG.L: "And, damesel, for thi chere,
And for my god sopere,
Thou shalt have my squiere,
Lok yf the paye;
Here i-gyf I ȝow be band
An c. pownd worth of land,
To tak hyr by the hond,
And do as y the saye."
Whan here trouthus were plyȝthe,
Sone torches were i-lyȝthe,
And gaff hym ordyr of knyȝthe,
For sothe as I say.
"Recumaunde, for Godys pyne,
To my lady and thinne,
As thou wolt that I be thin,
To my dethus day!

LG.HEAD: LVI.
LG.L: "Recumaund me pryvaly
To that fayre lady,
Or hur thonke lyȝtherely
That I am pore;
Ther shal emporoure ne kyng,
That shal hyr to bed bryng,
That I shall make a lettyng,
I sey the tho sothe.
Here my trouth I the plyȝthe,
Seyn fyrst I see hyr with syȝthe,
I sleped never o nyȝthe
Halvendel an houre!
Pray that corteys and hende
That sche wold be my frend,
And some socoure me send
ffor hyr mychel honowre."

LG.HEAD: LVII.
LG.L: The maid seis, "I take on hand,
That I shal do thyn errand,
Or I be flemyd out of lond,
Y lete for no dred;
I shall teche the a gyn
Out of this castel to wyn,
And how thou shal come in
Thyn erond to spede.
Ther ys a place in the wall,
Bytwyne the chaumbur and the hal,
Thor lyȝthe a mychel watur-wal
Of fourty feyt brede:
Ther shalt thou come in a nyȝthe
Prevaly withouten syȝth,
And here thi chaumbur shal by dyȝt,
And I can ryȝth rede."

LG.HEAD: LVIII.
LG.L: "Damesel, for Godus grace,
Teche me to that ylke place."
The maid prevaly apace
Passes byfore,
And ledes hym out at a gate,
In at a watur-ȝate,
Ther men vytayled by bate
That castel with cornes.
"At ebbe of the see,
Thou shalt not wad to the kne."
The knyȝt kyst that fre.
Erly at the morow
ffayir thei passed that flode,
To tho forest thei ȝoud,
And toke here stedus where thei stod
Undur the hawthrone.

LG.HEAD: LIX.
LG.L: Syre Degrivaunt ys whom went
And aftyr hys reten sent;
To that gret tornament
Thei busked hem ȝare.
But leve we now that gentyl knyȝt,
And spek we of that byrd bryȝt;
How thei gestened that nyȝt
Carp wyll we mare.
Erly one the mowroun
The lady louȝh hyr to scorne,
Sche seys, "Thi maydynhed is lorne,
God gyf the care!"
"Maydame, gyff hyt so be,
Hyt deres no man but me!
I fouchesaff on that fre,
And hyt so ware."

LG.HEAD: LX.
LG.L: Tho lady louȝhwes uppon hyȝt,
"Damesele, for Godys myȝt,
How peyis the that knyȝt,
As evere mote thou the?"
"I dare make myn avaunt
ffor my lord syre Degrivaunt,
Corteys and avenaunt,
I know non so fre!
Sertaynly this ylke nyȝthe,
Hys squier ys mad knyȝthe,
He and I ys trouthe plyȝthe
My housbond to be;
And he hath gyf us by band,
An c. pownd worth of land:
Here the chartur in thi hand,
Thiself may hyt see!"

LG.HEAD: LXI.
LG.L: Than that lady was glad
By sche that chartur had rad,
"Had thou syre Degrivaunant had,
Then had thou wel i-gon."
"Nay, meydame, so mot I thryve,
Ther ys now lady on lyve,
That he wol wed to wyff,
But only the allone.
Y warne the of o thing,
Ther shall be emporoure ne kyng,
That shal the to bede bryng,
I owttake none,
That hee wol make a lettyng;
He sendys the syche a gretyng,
Lo! here ys a rede gold ryng,
With a ryche stone."

LG.HEAD: LXII.
LG.L: The lady loked on that ryng,
Hyt was a gyfte fore a kyng,
"This ys a merveylous thing!
Wenus thou I be wode
To do syche a ffoly,
To love my lordys enemy,
Thow he were to so dowȝty?
Nay, by the rode!
Y do the wele for to wyte,
Y nel non housbond have ȝyte:
Seye the knyȝthe whan ȝe mete,
I wol hym no gude!
The duk of Gerle hase i-hyȝt
That he wol soupe here this nyȝt,
And gyf my chaumbur were i-dyȝt,
Nothing for-ȝeed."

LG.HEAD: LXIII.
LG.L: The duk ys comen over the see
With a ful grete meyné;
The eorl cortays and fre
ffayre hym gan praye
To dwel at hys costage,
At bouche and court and wage,
With knyȝt, squiere, and page,
Tyl the tent day.
A thousaund hors and thre
Of the dukus meyné
Ylke nyȝt tok lyveré
Off cowrne and off hay;
The ryche duk whan he eet,
The eorle hertely hym hete,
And with mayd Myldore the swet,
To have hyre for ay.

LG.HEAD: LXIV.
LG.L: The k[n]yȝthus of the eorles house
Held the duk so chyvalrous,
ffor he was gay and amorous,
And made hyt so tow.
The eorl tol[d] hym anon,
What armes he hadde cone,
And how hys chyvalré was slone
Undir the wod bowe.
"The baneret that wonnes here by
Wol asayl the cry,
He wroȝthe me this vylany,
And dud me this wouȝhe!"
The duk answerus on hyȝthe,
"Here my trouth I the plyȝthe,
Whedur he wol tornay of fyȝthe,
He shal have i-now!"

LG.HEAD: LXV.
LG.L: The duk answerus on hyȝthe,
"Wherby k[n]owus thou the knyȝthe?"
The eorle tauȝth hym ful ryȝthe,
With wordys, I wene.
"He beres in cheef of azour,
Engrelyd with a satur,
With doubule tressour,
And treweloves bytwene;
Hys bagges this blake,
ffor he wol no man forsake,
A lyoun tyed to an ake
Off gold and of grene:
An helme ryche to behold;
He beres a dolfyn of gold,
With trewelovus in the mold,
Compasyd ful clene.

LG.HEAD: LXVI.
LG.L: "He ys a lyoun in feld,
When he ys spred undur scheld!
Hys helme shal be wel steled,
That stond shal as stak:
He ys so stalloworth in stoure,
By seynt Martyn of Toure,
Couthe he love paramoure,
I k[n]ew never hys mak!
All the londes that I welde,
Wold I gyf in my ȝelde,
To se hym falde in the feld,
Ho wold hyt undurtake."
The duk louȝh hym to scorune,
Hys othe heyly has i-swrun,
"He shal abye to mowrun,
Syre, for thi sake!"

LG.HEAD: LXVII.
LG.L: And on morow the duk hym dyȝthe,
Also fast as he miȝthe,
The eorl hardy and wyȝthe,
Cruel and kene.
The sonne schonne en clere,
They uschen in with banere,
v. hunderyd knyȝtus in fere,
I-armed ful clene,
And the servitourus by-syde:
All that contray so wyde
Come thedur that tyde,
That solas to sene.
Sire [D]egrivaunt out of the west
Brouȝth out of the fforest
Thre hundred knyȝttus of the best,
Was greythed al on grene.

LG.HEAD: LXVIII.
LG.L: Ther was non so hardy,
That durst asayl the cry;
The held this duk so douȝty,
ffor hys mychel pryd.
But when thei se syre Degrivans
Com armed up a ferauns,
Thei thonked Gode of here shaunce,
All that other syde!
Then thei drowe hym ful nere,
Baneret and bachelere,
To ben undur hys banere,
To tornay that tyde,
With trompe and with nakere,
And the scalmuse clere;
ffolke frouschen in fere,
In herd ys not to hyde.

LG.HEAD: LXIX.
LG.L: And when the renkus gane mete,
ffele was fouled undur fete,
Knyȝthus strewed in the strete,
Stonyȝed with stedys;
With swerdus smartely thei smyt,
The temes sadely ful tyte,
Ther was no lengur delyte,
These worthely in wedus!
Baronus syttys on the bent
With shuldrys shamly shent;
Bryȝthe browus and bent
Brodelyche bledus!
Manye harmes has thei hent,
That was never at hore asent,
To come to that tornament,
To do suche dedus.

LG.HEAD: LXX.
LG.L: Syre Degrivaunt, withouten les,
Prykkus fast therow the pres;
To the cheventayn he ches,
And rauȝth hym a strok:
The duk dotered to the ground,
On erthe swyfftly he swouned,
Syre Degrivaunt, within a stound,
He wan hys sted blak.
He was stalworȝth in stoure,
ffor he loved paramoure;
The lady lay in the toure
That shuld be hys mak.
Syre Degrivaunt, are he blan,
This sey many a man,
Syxty stedus he wan,
And brouȝth to stak.

LG.HEAD: LXXI.
LG.L: Syre Degrevaunt every day,
The sertayn soth for to say,
Al the prys of the play
Was put on that fre;
Sone that douȝty undur sheld
Had y-venkessyd the feld,
Many a man hym byheld,
So hardy was he!
Ladyes seyden al-bydene,
Bothe contasse and qwene,
"ȝond gentyl knyȝt on grene
Hath deservyd the gre!"
Bryȝthe burdus in ther boure
Loved that knyȝth paramoure,
Gret ladyes of honoure,
And that hym seyen.

LG.HEAD: LXXII.
LG.L: The duk was horsed agayn,
And prycked fast thorw the playne;
The eorl and he with a trayn
To the castel gan fare:
Thane an heroud gon crye,
And prayd al the chyvalrye
To soupe at the maungerye,
Gyff ther wyllus ware.
The good knyȝt syre Degrivaunce,
He had y-made repurveaunce
ffor al hys retenaunce,
Fourty days and mare,
In the syde at a fel,
At a wel feyre castel,
Whyle hym was lefte for to dwel,
ffor to sle care.

LG.HEAD: LXXIII.
LG.L: The sterne knyȝthus and the stout,
Whylk that tornyment without,
Ryden away in hys rout,
Thre hundred and mo;
And c. pound and a stede
He send the mynstralus to mede,
Off gyffte was he never gnede,
ffor wele nor for wo!
Tyl hys castel he rade,
A ryal maungerye he made,
Alle the bold ther abade,
Ther scapyd non hym fro.
At even seyd syr Degrivauns,
"I wol se the countenauns
Of the chyvalrye of Frauns,
As ever mote I go!"

LG.HEAD: LXXIV.
LG.L: Syr [D]egrivaunt at evyn-lyȝthus
Armed hym at al ryȝthus,
And callyd to hym tolly knyȝthus,
That pryvest were ay;
"Have dyȝt ȝow on stedus
In two damysel wedus,
ffor I wol found in my nedus
As fast as I may.
Tak ether of ȝow a spere,
Bothe of pes and of were,
Greyth myn hors on hore gere,
And lok that thei be gay;
That they be trapped a get,
In topteler and in mauntolet,
In a fyn vyolet,
And makes non delay."

LG.HEAD: LXXV.
LG.L: And whan here hors were held,
Thei toke ther sperus and there scheldus,
And prycked fast over the felde,
No lenger wolde thei dwel;
And sy[th]en thei ryden even west
Thorw a fayr forest,
With two trompess of the best,
That range as a bell.
On an hull he gan hym rest,
Thei gaf hym hys helm in hys rest,
He was the sternest gest
ffro heven to helle!
Syr Degrivaunt, withouten abad,
To the eorlus castel he rade,
He found the ȝat so brad,
Swyche hap hym felle.

LG.HEAD: LXXVI.
LG.L: And rydes up to the des,
As thei were servid of here mes,
To mayd Myldor he ches,
And chalangys that fre!
The duk sterte up an hyȝt,
"Here my trouthe y the plyȝt,
I shal delyver the this bryȝt,
To-morow shalt thou se,
Bytwene undurne and prime;
Loke at thou come at that tyme,
Other swowne shal i[n] sweme,
The lady shall i-se.
And trewly, withouten les,
Thou shalt be servid, or I sess,
Bothe of werre and of pess,
Of ayther cours thre."

LG.HEAD: LXXVII.
LG.L: The knyȝth was so dressé,
Hytt was gret joye to se,
So fayre an hors-man as he
Seye thei never are;
Some loked one hys stede,
And some on hys rych wede,
And some the resone gan rede
What the knyȝthe bare.
He loutes down to them alle,
Bothe to the [riche] and to the smalle,
And rydys out of the halle,
And buskys hym ȝare.
Of all that loked one the knyȝt,
Was non that knew hym with syȝt,
Bot mayden Myldor the bryȝt,
Of all that ther ware.

LG.HEAD: LXXVIII.
LG.L: Hammard he rydes ryȝth,
And as fast as he myȝth,
On the mowro he hym dyȝth
Ryȝth as he dude are;
And fyndys the duk in the feld,
Bothe with spere and with sche[l]d:
The eorl hoved and byheld,
Brem as a bare!
Than seid the duke one the land,
"Whare ys now this geand?
He wol hald no covenand,
ffor alle hys gret fare!"
But when he say syre Degrivaunt
Come armed up a fferauns,
Hys hert wex recreaunt,
And syȝth ful sare!

LG.HEAD: LXXIX.
LG.L: The duke send a squiere
To wytt what hys wyll were,
To juste o pesse or off were,
So sore he hym dredus!
The knyȝt answerd ther-tyll,
Bothe with resone and with skyll,
"Hyt shal be at hys wyll,
Tak hap what ledus!"
Then the douȝthy hym dyȝth
As faste as thei myȝth,
Thei set helmus on hyȝth,
Thes douȝty on dedus:
To gret sperus of pese
Bothe these lordes hem chese,
And prikes fast thorw the prese
Opon stout stedus.

LG.HEAD: LXXX.
LG.L: Ther stedes styrres hom faste,
The knyȝthus jusset or thy cast,
Ther good speres al to-brast,
That weren gode at nede;
Syr Degrivaunt, as he had ment,
And gaf the duk swych a dynt,
That bothe styroppus he tynt,
And hond I the hete.
The duke rekyvered aȝyne,
Hys frenchepys were fayn,
The proford hym payn-mayn,
Vernage and Crete;
The duk swore by gret God of hevene,
"Wold my hors so evene,
ȝet wold I sett all one seven
ffor Myldor the swet!"

LG.HEAD: LXXXI.
LG.L: Tow gret sperus ha they ton,
And gerd there stedus whyll the gron!
Wytt ȝow wel that many on
Lokede on them two;
The douȝty knyȝthus of pryde,
Thorw the renckus gon thei ryde,
Bote they myssede at that tyde,
Thorw hap hyt fell so.
The good knyȝth, syre Auntorus,
Come in at the thryd cours,
ffor he loved paramours,
In hert that he was thro,
And strykus the duk thorw the scheld,
Wyd opon in the feld;
The eorl hoved and byheld,
In hert he was wo!

LG.HEAD: LXXXII.
LG.L: The damessel toke the stede,
And thorw the renkus gone hym lede,
And seys, "Have this for thi mede,
Tyl thou gete mo."
ȝet she spekys a word of pride,
"On this stede wol I ryde
By my lemmanus syde,
I[n] lond whare I go."
That knyȝt dressyd hym in hys gere,
Hys felawe rauȝth hym a spere,
A scharpe wepon of were,
The duk for to slo;
And seis, "Syre duke avenaunt,
I pray the hold couvenaunt,
ȝondur ys a knyȝthe erraunt,
Why taryest thou hym so?"

LG.HEAD: LXXXIII.
LG.L: The duk lay on the grownd,
On erthe swyftely he swound,
He was stonyed that stownd,
Trewely that tyde;
And ȝit she cryes upone hyȝth,
"ȝondur ys armed a knyȝth,
All redy and y-dyȝth,
Thi comes for to abyde."
The duke answerd ther-tyle,
Bothe with reson and skyle,
"I am y-hurte ful yle,
In herd is not to hyde!
Pray hym tak hit nat a-greff,
He ses I am at myscheff,
Y hathe nat y my lyff,
So sore ys my syde!"

LG.HEAD: LXXXIV.
LG.L: Syre Degrivaunt toke hys stede,
And gaff the mynstrallus to mede,
And to forest thei spede
As faste as the may;
The duke that was this y-dyȝt,
He toke his leve that ylk nyȝt
Bothe with baroun and with knyȝt,
And went one hys way.
Sire Degrivaunt on the morwoun
Com aȝé to the thorun,
Ther hys stede stod by-forun,
And lenges all that day;
Privayly at the nyȝth
He come in with hys knyȝth,
To spek with Myldore the bryȝth,
Spede yf he may.

LG.HEAD: LXXXV.
LG.L: The mayde wyst by a gyne,
That the knyȝth was comen in;
The lady of heye kyne
Perseved the thouȝth.
"Damesele, so have I rest,
Thou hast geton the a gest
Off wylde men of the west,
Delayne thou hom nouȝth;
Privayly withouten syȝth
Do me carp with that knyȝth,
Here my trouȝth y the plyȝth,
Hee has dere y-bouȝth!"
Thanne the mayden was glade,
Sche dude as the lady bade,
And up at the grese hoe him lade,
And to chaumbur hym brouȝth."

LG.HEAD: LXXXVI.
LG.L: The lady of honowre
Metes the [knyȝt] in the doure,
Knelyd doun in the floure,
And fel hym to feet;
ffrek as fuyre in the flynt
He in armes had hyre hynt,
And thrytty sythes, are he stynt,
He kyst that swet!
"Welcome, syre Aunterous,
Me thenkus thou art mervelous;
Wyst my lord of this hous,
With grame [he] wolde the gret!"
Swythe chayres was i-sete,
And quyschonus of vyolete,
Thus this semely was i-sete
With mouth for to mete.

LG.HEAD: LXXXVII.
LG.L: "Damesele, loke ther be
A ffuyre in the chymené,
ffagattus of fyre tre,
That fetchyd was ȝare."
Sche sett a bourd of yvore,
Trestellus ordeyned therfor,
Clothus keverede that over,
Swyche seye thei never are!
Towellus of Eylyssham,
Whyȝth as the seeys fame,
Sanappus of the same,
Thus servyd thei ware;
With a gyld salere,
Basyn and ewere,
Watyr of everrose clere,
They wesche ryȝth thare.

LG.HEAD: LXXXVIII.
LG.L: Paynemayn prevayly
Sche brouȝth fram the pantry,
And served that semely,
Same ther thei seet.
Sche brouȝt fram the kychene
A scheld of a wylde swynne,
Hastelettus in galantyne,
An hand y ȝow hete.
Seththe sche brouȝt hom in haste,
Ploverys poudryd in paste,
Ther ware metus with the maste,
I do ȝow to wytte;
ffatt conyngus and newe,
ffesauntus and corelewe,
Ryche she tham drewe
Vernage and Crete.

LG.HEAD: LXXXIX.
LG.L: To tell here metus was tere,
That was served at here sopere,
Ther was no dentethus to dere,
Ne spyces to spare;
And evere sche drow hom the wyn,
Bothe the Roche and the Reyn,
And the good Malvesyn,
ffelde sche hom ȝare.
And evere Myldore sche sete
Harpyng notus ful swet,
And other whyle sche et,
Whan hur leveste ware;
Songe ȝeddyngus above,
Swyche murthus they move,
In the chaumbur of love
Thus thei sleye care!

LG.HEAD: XC.
LG.L: Ther was a ryall rooffe
In the chaumbur of loffe,
Hyt was buskyd above
With besauntus ful bryȝth
All off ruel bon,
Whyȝth oger and parpon,
Mony a dere wrothe stone,
Endentyd and dyȝthe.
Ther men myȝth se, ho that wolde,
Arcangelus of rede golde,
ffyfty mad of o molde,
Lowynge ful lyȝth;
With the Pocalyps of Jon,
The Powlus Pystolus everychon,
The Parabolus of Salamon
Payntyd ful ryȝth.

LG.HEAD: XCI.
LG.L: And the foure gospellorus
Syttyng on pyllorus;
Hend, herkeneth and herus,
Gyf hyt be ȝoure wyll.
Austyn and Gregory,
Jerome and Ambrose,
Thus the foure doctorus
Lystened than tylle:
There was purtred in ston
The fylesoferus everychon,
The story of Absolon,
That lyked ful ylle;
With an orrelegge one hyȝth
To rynge the ours at nyȝth,
To waken Myldore the bryȝth,
With bellus to knylle.

LG.HEAD: XCII.
LG.L: Square wyndowus of glas,
The rechest that ever was,
Tho moynelus was off bras
Made with menne handus;
Alle the wallus of geete,
With gaye gablettus and grete,
Kynggus syttyng in ther sete
Out of sure londus.
Grete Charlus with the crounne,
Syre Godfray the Boyloune,
And Arthur the Bretoune,
With here bryȝt broundus.
The floure was paned over-al
With a clere crystal,
And overe keveryd with a pal,
A-fflore where she stondes.

LG.HEAD: XCIII.
LG.L: Hur bede was off aszure,
With testur and celure,
With a bryȝt bordure
Compasyd ful clene;
And all a storye as hit was
Of Ydoyne and Amadas,
Perreye in ylke a plas,
And papageyes of grene.
The scochenus of many knyȝt
Of gold and cyprus was i-dyȝt,
Brode besauntus and bryȝt,
And trewelovus bytwene;
Ther was at hur testere
The kyngus owne banere:
Was nevere bede rychere
Of empryce ne qwene!

LG.HEAD: XCIV.
LG.L: ffayre schetus of sylk
Chalk-whyȝth as the mylk,
Quyltus poyned of that ylk,
Touseled they ware;
Coddys of sendall,
Knoppus of crystal,
That was mad in Westfal
With women of lare.
Hyt was a mervelous thing
To se the rydalus hyng,
With mony a rede gold ryng,
That home up bare;
The cordes that thei one ran,
The duk Betyse hom wan,
Mayd Medyore hom span
Of meré maydenus hare.

LG.HEAD: XCV.
LG.L: Ryȝt abouȝt mydnyȝt,
Seyd syre Degrivaunt the knyȝt,
"When wolt thou, the worthely wyȝt,
Lysten me tyll?
ffor love my hert wyl to-brest,
When wylt thou bryng me to rest?
Lady, wysse me the [best],
Gyf hyt be thi wyll."
The burde answered [ffulle ȝa]re,
"Nevene thou that eny mare,
Thou schalt rew hit ful sare,
And lyke hit ful ylle!
Sertes tho thou were a kyng,
Thou touchest non swych thing,
Or thou wed me with a ryng,
And maryage fulfylle!

LG.HEAD: XCVI.
LG.L: "Leff thou well, withouten lette,
The ferste tyme y the mette,
Myn hert on the was sette,
And my love on the lyȝth!
I thouȝthe never to have non
Lord nothur lemman,
Bot onely the allon;
Caysere ne knyȝth,
Kyng ne non conquerour,
Ne no lord of honour,
And gyff hit were the emperour,
Most proved of myȝth!
ffor-thy, syre, hald the stylle,
Whyle thou get my fadyr wylle."
Tho knyȝt sentus ther-tylle,
And trouthus thei plyȝth.

LG.HEAD: XCVII.
LG.L: And whan here trouthus was plyȝt,
Than here hertus were lyȝt,
Was never faukons off flyȝt
So fayn as thei ware!
Thai lay doun in ther bede,
In ryche clothus was spred,
Wytte ȝe wel, or thei were wed,
Thei synnyd nat thare.
Than spekus tho burd bryȝth
To syre Degrivaunt the knyȝth,
"Swet syre, come ylke nyȝth,
And loke how we fare."
And the bold bachylere
Toke the damysele clere;
This thei dured that ȝere,
Thre [qua]rterus and mare.

LG.HEAD: XCVIII.
LG.L: At [mis]somere in a nyȝth,
The [mo]ne schone wondur bryȝt,
S[ire De]grivaunt and hys knyȝt
[Bu]sked to wend.
[The] douȝty knyȝthus so fre
[L]yȝth doun by a tre;
A prout fostere gane tham se
A-laund ther thei lende,
And folewes hom thorw the wode,
Alle the weyes that thei ȝode,
And how thei passed the flode,
The knyȝthus so hende:
So dud the weyt one the walle,
The eorlus owne mynstralle,
Sey tham wende to the halle,
And wyst nevere what hyt mende.

LG.HEAD: XCIX.
LG.L: The pypere haldus hys pays,
Tyl no man he hyt says;
Mynstralus shuld be cortays,
And skyl that thei ben.
The foster tolde anone-ryȝthus
To the eorle and hys knyȝthus,
How thei come armede a-nyȝthus,
As he hadde y-sen.
The styward was chyvalrous,
Syre Eymour the kayous,
With offycyrus of that hous,
Cruel and kene,
A gret buschement hadde he [sette],
Ther the fostere hom mette,
And thouȝth syre Degrivaunt lette
The wayes ful grene.

LG.HEAD: C.
LG.L: The stywarde heylé hath swornne,
"And he come be thi[s thor]nne,
We bryng hys he[d on th]e mornne,
And non othur mede!"
Dame Myldor w[ist righte no]uȝth
What al this folkys [had th]ouȝth,
She wende no man that ha[d ben]e wrouȝth
Hadde wyten of hore [dede];
And syre Degrivaunt hadde y-[hiȝt]h,
Ryȝth as he was trew knyȝth,
To speke with Myldore that nyȝth,
And lette for no drede.
God, as ȝe are muchel of myȝt,
Save syre Degrivaunt the knyȝt,
And lene hym grace in that fyȝt
Wel for to spede!

LG.HEAD: CI.
LG.L: Syre Degrivaunt at evene-lyȝth
Armede hym and hys knyȝth,
And toke on privayly for syȝth
Two gownes off grene;
Nothur schelde ne spere,
Ne no wepen of werre,
Bot twey swerdus thei berre
Off Florence ful kene.
Whan thei come to the slac,
The bolde buschament brac,
.......nte opone stedus bac
[Ar]mede ful clene.
[Si]re Degrivaunt, ys nat to layne,
[B]lyve hys swerde had y-drayne,
He that come formast was slayne
In the schaw schene!

LG.HEAD: CII.
LG.L: Whan thei syre Degrivaunt mett,
Sevene sperus one hym y-sett
Evene in hys bassonett
Brasten a-two.
Some bare hym thorw the gowne,
Some brast one hys haberjowne;
Hys sqwyere was borne downe,
Hys swerd cast hym fro!
Then syre Degrivaunt lyȝth,
And rescowede hys knyȝth,
And cryed to hym an hyȝth,
"Why wolt thou lyen so?"
The beste stedes that thei hade
By the scholders he them scharde,
He was never so hard y-stade
ffor wele ne for wo!

LG.HEAD: CIII.
LG.L: The styward syre Eymere
Com a lytyl to nere,
Hys hede by the colere
He kerves away!
The body syttys opon the hors,
Hyt was uncomely to the cors,
The stede stert over a fosse,
And strykys a-stray;
Y wyst never how hyt ferde.
He betus hom fast to the erthe;
With hys two-honde swerde
He made swyche paye,
That syxty lay one the feld,
Bothe with spere and with schelde,
That never wepen myȝth [welde]
Sen that ylke day!

LG.HEAD: CIV.
LG.L: The panter, the botelere,
The eorlus cheff sqwyere,
They lyes slay y-fere
In the schawe schene!
Than the remenaunt fles
On the sort that thei sees,
And some lorkus undur tres
In slowes unshene.
Thonkede be Godes grace,
He has venkest hys face,
And made a chyvalrous chace,
That crewel and kene!
Nouȝth fourty fot fram the wal,
He slowe the marchal of the hal,
And other gode sqwyers with-al,
Mo then fyftene!

LG.HEAD: CV.
LG.L: By that hyt dawed ney day,
By that he hade endyd this play,
Some scaped away,
And many one was slayne.
Than sayd syre Degrivaunt the knyȝt,
"Here my trouthe y the plyȝt,
I shal speke with Myldore to nyȝt,
To dey in the payne."
Thei set here stedus ther thei stode,
And fayre passede the flode,
To the eorlus castel the[i] ȝode
The gatus ful gayn:
Than the lady so bryȝth,
ffayre she welcomed the knyȝth;
She had nat hard [of] hore fyȝth,
Therof were thei fayn.

LG.HEAD: CVI.
LG.L: She had wondur in hyr wyt,
Why here clothus ware to-slyt,
As thei in holtus had byn hyt
With dyntus of spere:
[The]re gay gownus of grene
[We]re ful schamely be-sene;
"[Le]ve syre, where have ȝe bene,
[ȝoure] clothus to tere?"
The knyȝth sat semely,
And seide tyl hyre prevely,
"We sey [never selly]
That sh[oulde us] auȝth dere;
But as [we came] by a thorne,
Thus [wer ou]re gownus to-torne;
We sh[alle] have new to-morne,
We [cownt]e hyt not a payre."

LG.HEAD: CVII.
LG.L: The kniȝ[th] had fouȝten as a bare,
[Therfore h]ym fersted ful sare;
[The m]ayde brouȝth hym ful ȝare
[The s]pyces and the wyn.
Dyverse spices thei ete,
And ofte with mowthus thei mete;
Sche brouȝthe hem Vernage and Crete,
And wyne of the Reyne.
He toke his leve at the day
At mayde Myldore the may,
ȝet wyste ho note of the fray
That she hard sethȝne.
The knyȝth one wendys his way,
Ther the dede men lay,
And seyde soufft one his play,
"ȝondur was stout hyne!"

LG.HEAD: CVIII.
LG.L: Thei brouȝthe home on bere
The stywarde syre Eymere,
And other gode sqwyere,
Off fryththus unfayne;
And cryide out over alle,
Both gret and smalle.
The mayde wyndus to the halle
Tythyngus to frayne.
The ȝorle spekus to that fre,
"Y wytt syr Degrivaunt and the
The slauȝthtur of my mené;
This is ȝowre false treyne!
By Hym that dyede one tre,
This day shall thou [dede] be!
I wat welle hit [es he]
That hase the be[layne!]"

LG.HEAD: CIX.
LG.L: The mayde answer[d agayne],
And seis, "Peter! I [am f]ayne
And that knyȝth be [not slay]ne;
What bote is that I lye?
Sene he was chosene my fy[rst] make,
Shall I hym never forsake,
What dethe that I take,
Or dool that I drye!"
Thane the ȝorle wax wode,
And swore be bonus and blode,
"Mete ne drynk shall do me gode,
Ar I se the dye!"
The contasse knelyd tho anone,
"Gode schylde, syr, that he be slone,
We hade never chyl[d] but hyr one!"
And cryid ful hye.

LG.HEAD: CX.
LG.L: The contasse cryed, "Alas!
ȝe have ben to longe foas;
Wycked tonge hit mas,
God ȝif them shame!
I dare savely say,
The knyȝth went one his way,
[O]wre men by-sett hym the way,
[He] was not to blame.
[W]as not his fosteres slayne
While he werred in Spayne?
Hys woddys and hys waryne,
ȝe made hem alle tame!
Y rede ȝe sauȝthle with the knyȝt,
That is so hardy and wyȝth,
And graunte hym Myldore the bryȝt,
By hyr ryȝth name!"

LG.HEAD: CXI.
LG.L: Than spekus Myldore the bryȝth,
"Ther was but he and a knyȝth,
I spake with hym this nyȝth,
Why shulde I spare?
He is my love and my lorde,
Myne hele and my counforde,
Hyt is gode ȝe be a-corde,
And ȝowre wyllus ware:
And giff ȝe holde us a-gret,
Shall I never ete mete."
The ȝorl for angur gane swet,
And syȝthe ful sare;
"Damesele, ar thou be spylte,
I forgiff the the gylte,
Hit is alle as thou wylte;
I cane say na mare!"

LG.HEAD: CXII.
LG.L: Bylyve a lettur ho sent,
Thorw the ȝorlus comandment;
A messengere has hit hent,
With tythingus ful newe.
She bad hym cume prively
With hys best chyvalry,
As he was gode and douȝty,
And holdene for trewe;
And hoe shuld make swych acord
Bytwene hym and hur lorde,
That shulde be a coumforde
Tyl alle that hym ever knewe.
ȝet syr Degrivant hym drade,
Syxty knyȝthus he clade,
Tyl the ȝorlus castel he spede
By the day dewe.

LG.HEAD: CXIII.
LG.L: The ȝorle metus hym withoute,
With sterne knyȝthus and stoute,
Wonder low gane he loute,
And haylus that hende;
And says, "Syr, by Goddys grace,
Welcome to this place,
We have ben to longe fase,
Now wyl I be thi frende."
Prively that no man wyste,
Alle wrongus was redressyde,
The ȝorle and he hade keste,
And to chaumbur thei wende.
Withoutyne more rehersynge
Made was the sauȝthlynge,
And grauntyd hym Myldore the ȝinge
Tille hys lyves ende.

LG.HEAD: CXIV.
LG.L: Was never sych a purvyaunce
In Englond ne in Fraunce,
As was at sir Degrivaunce
And Myldore the schene;
Ther com tyl hir weddyng
An emperoure and a kyng,
Erchebyschopbz with ryng
Mo then fyftene!
The mayster of hospitalle
Come over with a cardinalle,
The gret kyng of Portyngalle,
With knyȝthus ful kene;
Alle the lordys of that lond
War holy at that offorand,
And ladyes, y undyrstond,
Emperyce and qwene!

LG.HEAD: CXV.
LG.L: One the Trinité day,
Thus in romance herd y say,
He toke hyr in Godus lay
Tylle hys lyvys ende.
Solempnely a cardinal,
Revescyd with a pontifical,
Sang the masse ryal,
And wedded that hend.
And the ryche Emperoure
Gaff [hyre] at the kyrke dore,
With w[orschy]p and honoure,
As f[or hi]s owne frend;
And [sa]w gold in that stonde,
W[elle] a thowsand pounde,
Lay glyterynge in the gronde,
By the way as thei wende!

LG.HEAD: CXVI.
LG.L: Thane the semelede the sale,
Kyng and cardynale,
And the emperoure ryale,
With barnus ful bolde;
So dud ladies bydene,
Both contasse and qwene,
Bryȝth burdys and schene,
Was joye to beholde!
ffro the mangery bygane,
Wyne in condyt rane
Redy tyll ylke mane,
Take ho so wolde.
Ther com in a daunse
IX. doseperus of Fraunce,
Methowȝth syche a countynaunce
Was joye to beholde!

LG.HEAD: CXVII.
LG.L: I knewe never mane so wys,
That couth telle the servise,
Ne scrye the metys of prys
Was servyd in that sale;
Mynstrallus hade in halle
Grete gyftys withalle,
Ryche robus of palle,
With garnementus hale.
Ylke day that fourtynyȝth
Justyng of seryd knyȝthus,
To revele ho best myȝth,
With wyne and with ale;
And one the fyftethe day,
Thus in romaunce h[erd I] say,
They toke here leve and [wen]t here way,
Thys worthely to w......

LG.HEAD: CXVIII.
LG.L: Al thei maketh ther avaunt
Off the lord syre Degrivaunt,
Cortays and avenaunt,
Ladyes and knyȝthus.
He gaff stedus that stound
Worth a thousand pound,
Withouten haukes and hound,
And faukun of flyȝthus!
The ȝorle dyede that same ȝere,
And the contasse clere;
Bothe hore beryelus y-ffere
Was gayly bydyȝth.
Syr Degrivaunt bylefte ther eyre,
With brod londus and faire,
Was never perus myȝth hym peyre
By resone ne ryȝth.

LG.HEAD: CXIX.
LG.L: Thrytty wyntur and mare
Thei lyvede to-gydur without care,
And sevene chyldur she hym bare,
That worthly in wede;
And sene sche dyed, y undurstond,
He seysed hys eyre with hys hond,
And went into the Holy Lond,
Hevene be hys mede!
At Port-gaff was he slone,
ffor-justyd with a Soudone:
Thus to Gode is he gone,
Thus douȝty in dede!
Lord Gode in Trinité
Gyff hem Heven for to see,
That loves gamene and gle,
And gestus to fede!
